results.title: A discovery of freedom
results.brief_description: A unique perspective on the Eureka Stockade story created by a Eureka 150 youth ambassador in a special Digital Storytelling Workshop to celebrate 150 years since the famous rebellion. This story is a document of 17 year-old Tom’s experiences in the Eureka 150 youth team. “..I realised that my freedoms and rights were things I had taken for granted”.

results.title: Democracy forged in a gun barrel
results.brief_description: A unique perspective on the Eureka Stockade story created by a Eureka 150 youth ambassador in a special Digital Storytelling Workshop to celebrate 150 years since the famous rebellion. “Eureka to me is true Australian grit and courage. It’s about people standing up against injustice and believing in a cause greater than themselves”.

results.title: Noise: polluting the environment
results.creator_credit: Thomas Smith and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in Crisis”.
A study of noise pollution as exemplified by the problems emanating from traffic noises and the noise of aircraft in residential areas. Although made in 1971, the issue of noise pollution is even more significant in 2002.

results.title: Controversy over industrial pollution: a case study
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Luther Gerlach and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in Crisis”.
Anaconda Aluminium Company opened a plant at Columbia Falls, Montana. In 1968, after a plant explosion, poisonous fluoride emissions began to damage trees for miles around. All sides of the resulting controversy are presented objectively in this film,which should spark discussion of the environmental crisis in general and of the scientific, social and economic issues involved in finding solutions to pollution problems

results.title: Chaucer and the Medieval Period
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English Literature”.
Provides a background for the study of medieval English literature. Identifies the early literary forms - the ballad, mystery play, allegory and romance - and shows how each of these was an expression of different aspects of medieval society. Re-enactments of portions of the Canterbury Tales; Piers Plowman; Sir Gawain and the Green Knight; Morte d’Arthur, illustrate the variety and vigor with which medieval literature is endowed. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Romantic period
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English Literature”.
Illustrates the literary and political revolution that occurred in the early part of the nineteenth century. Dramatised selections from Burns, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Blake, Byron, Shelley, Keats and Scott reveal the individuality and independence of spirit of England’s Romantic writers.

results.title: The Victorian period
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English Literature”.
Recreates the atmosphere of 19th century England as a background to the writings of men and women of that period. Presents extracts from the works of Macauley, Darwin, Huxley, Newman, Dickens, the Bronte sisters, Hardy, Arnold, Ruskin and Carroll. Mentions the industrial revolution and new scientific discoveries as prominent features in the writings of these people.

results.title: Norman Conquest to the fifteenth century
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English History”.
Presents an overall view of medieval England from the Norman Conquest in 1066 to the decline of feudalism during the time of Henry V. Discusses the limited monarchy as the basis of the English form of democracy and explains the importance of trial by jury and the Magna Carta in the recognition and growth of human rights in Britain.
